awd_titl_txt: 2017 NSF Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) Grantees Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the current socioeconomic and political landscape, increased levels of accountability are being faced in many scientific areas.  As a result, funding agencies have been paying significant attention to increasing the impact of their research investments. This project will bring together approximately 200 researchers from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) Division for a meeting to be held in the Washington, DC, metropolitan area in the fall of 2017. During the two-and-a-half-day conference, EEC grantees will have opportunities to collaborate, share promising practices, and learn about state-of-the-art and ongoing efforts that could help them increase the impact of their projects. By having a focus on impact, the proposed conference contributes to the broader conversation to characterize and meaningfully communicate insights about the outcomes of NSF investments in areas such as engineering education research, broadening participation in engineering, and workforce development. 

Staff from the American Society for Engineering Education will consult with a four-member planning committee, comprising EEC grantees, to plan and organize the meeting. The meeting will include plenary talks and panels, concurrent sessions, poster sessions featuring grantees' projects, and networking sessions. The interactive components of the meeting will be designed and structured to emphasize conscious collaboration and to maximize cross-pollination among grantees. Conference attendees will provide feedback via two mechanisms: (a) immediate post-conference survey, and (b) six-month follow-up survey. ASEE will produce a written summary of the meeting that includes summaries of plenary talks, summary analyses of the relevant breakout discussions (focusing on lessons that can be shared among grantees), and results from the evaluation survey. The proposed meeting provides a cost- and time-effective opportunity for EEC grantees to share their research, discuss current directions and challenges, and explore new opportunities and partnerships for future work. This meeting also represents an opportunity for the EEC community to draw upon knowledge that is currently tacit within individual projects, as well as highlight emerging knowledge about the characterization and effective communication of project impacts within and outside of the engineering education ecosystem.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) Division has an expansive research portfolio clustered in four areas: Centers and Networks, Engineering Education, Broadening Participation in Engineering, and Engineering Workforce Development. Through this award, the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) leveraged the intellectual affinity across various NSF EEC grantee clusters and programs by (1) fostering knowledge sharing across the network of grantees; (2) cultivating personal and professional collaborations and partnerships among grantees; and (3) informing grantees about state-of-the-art and ongoing efforts to help increase the impact of NSF awards. Activities included the implementation of a national conference, a workshop series, a digital repository, and a webinar series.

The 2017 NSF EEC Grantees Conference was held on October 29-31, 2017 in Arlington, Virginia. It brought together principal investigators (PIs) and team leaders from seven EEC programs, across three clusters (Engineering Education, Broadening Participation in Engineering, and Engineering Workforce Development) to share and explore ideas aimed at promoting innovation in engineering education research, with the overall goal of increasing the impact of EEC-funded projects. More than 260 people attended, including ten students participating in the Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) program, and ten teachers participating in Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) program. Conference attendees noted that they were able to expand their vision of impact through the conference sessions, where they learned about work being done by others, how it relates to their own projects, and how impact can go beyond individual projects and have a larger scientific, cross-disciplinary, and societal footprint. The conference report is available at: https://docs.asee.org/public/EEC/2017EECConferenceReport.pdf.

From Identity to Impact is a hybrid workshop series for early career engineering education researchers, with the goals of helping participants (1) build capacity in formulating engineering research and innovation impact identities and (2) communicate the impact of their research effectively. The series was comprised of one half-day face-to-face workshop, held in October 2019 in conjunction with the 2019 NSF EEC Grantees Conference, and two 90-minute live online workshops, held online in January 2019. The face-to-face workshop was targeted towards early career researchers who were attending the 2019 EEC Grantees Conference--this workshop was attended by 14 individuals. The online workshops were targeted towards graduate students, doctoral students, and post-doctoral students--the first workshop was attended by 14 individuals, the second by 10 individuals.

ASEE Resource Central (https://resources.asee.org) is a searchable online repository of curated resources launched to support the engineering education community during the COVID-19 pandemic. Resource Central comprises 185+ informational and educational resources on a variety of relevant and timely topics, including remote teaching, remote labs and capstone, and student support. Resources include articles, webinars, web-based repositories, blog posts, podcasts, and video clips, many of which are related to pedagogical innovations for online and hybrid environments. Since the launch of ASEE Resource Central in April 2020, the site's homepage has received 4,000+ pageviews and it now includes ASEE course catalog. The site has been institutionalized and will be maintained by ASEE after the end of the grant.

The webinar series was comprised of 15 webinars with 4,000+ overall registrants and 2,000+ attendees. Each webinar offered attendees opportunities to engage with speakers and one another while gaining awareness of novel content and actionable strategies. The series included the following webinars:

  • Building and Cultivating Strategic Relationships
  • Going from Research to Impact in Engineering Education: Insights on Impediments and Opportunities
  • Increase the Impact of your Journal Publications
  • Demystifying Evaluation - Promising Practices to Maximize Your DEI Efforts
  • What's Your Story? Using Storytelling to Propel Research and Teaching
  • Learning What Matters: A Novel Approach to Study and Adapt to the Real-time Impacts of COVID-19 on Engineering Education
  • Designing a Remote Internship: An Entrepreneurial Learning Experience
  • Emerging Insights on Navigating Remote Labs
  • Emerging Insights on Navigating Remote Instruction
  • Emerging Insights on Navigating Remote Student Support
  • Supporting Underrepresented Engineering Students in the Time of COVID-19
  • Supporting Engineering Graduate Students in The Time Of COVID-19
  • Learning in the Time of Coronavirus
  • Writing Effective COVID Impact Statements: Emerging Insights and Best Practices
  • Reflective Teaching in a Digital Age

All webinars were recorded and are available on-demand on Resource Central (https://resources.asee.org/course-catalog/).


Last Modified: 12/15/2021
Modified by: Rocio C Chavela Guerra
